The rates for trade taxes were based on a percentage of the value of goods, but the total amounts were then divided among different regions and collecting offices in absolute numbers. Any excess amount collected by a local official was meant for the operation of the office or for their personal use. There were occasional instances of honest officials who, in accordance with Confucian principles, refrained from collecting more than the specified quota, earning admiration from the merchants.
The state strictly regulated the sale of salt, with households responsible for delivering their production to state warehouses. Quotas were determined based on the number of able-bodied men, with the Hongwu era setting the quota at 3,200 jin (1,900 kg) per year per man. In exchange for every 400 jin (240 kg) of salt delivered, households received one dan (107 liters) of rice for sustenance. The state then distributed the salt to licensed merchants who were authorized to sell it throughout the country. These merchants were required to obtain a license through the kaizhong system, which was granted in exchange for supplying grain to the northern borders.
After paper money (banknotes) was introduced, salt producers were paid with it instead of grains, but due to the inflation of banknotes, the payments were eventually abolished and the salt levy became a poll tax. As a result, the number of registered salt producers decreased while production continued to keep up with population growth. This led to a large amount of salt being sold on the black market. In the 15th century, in an attempt to control the black market, the state allowed licensed merchants to buy back excess salt from producers and collected an excise tax from them. Producers preferred to sell their salt rather than pay the tax, causing the black market to thrive. By the early 16th century, the black market had already taken over "official" supplies in some regions. According to estimates from the Ministry of Revenue and censors, three-quarters of the salt from the Lianghuai region was being sold on the black market by the mid-16th century.
In the late 15th century, salt merchants began to specialize in their trade. One group would deliver grain to the border and sell delivery receipts to wholesalers in the salt-producing regions. The other group would negotiate with salt offices and producers, and then sell the salt to distributors who would distribute it throughout the country. The main hub of the salt trade was Yangzhou, and most of the wholesalers there came from Huizhou. This trade required a significant amount of capital, especially from wholesalers, as the process from grain delivery to salt sales could take anywhere from three to ten years. The system was often inefficient, with deliveries regularly being delayed by two to three years.
In 1492, the government implemented a new policy that allowed silver to be used in the purchase of salt trading licenses. This reform was also applied to the tea market. Starting in 1535, granaries in the northern regions began issuing certificates that allowed merchants to access previously restricted salt-producing areas, purchase a set amount of salt, and also buy any excess salt directly from the producers.
By 1578, the official trade of salt had reached 508,000 tons, resulting in an estimated annual state income of 2 million liang of silver. Of this income, a quarter was used for goods delivered to the northern frontier, while the remaining three-quarters was intended for military expenses.
The state's minor revenues consisted of twenty-six relatively small items, including 344,000 liang of silver from internal customs, 150,000 liang of silver from local trade taxes, income from mines (150,000), proceeds from the sale of ranks (510,000 in 1565), the sale of licenses for Buddhist and Taoist monks (200,000), and compensation for punishments (300,000). In total, the state collected approximately 3 million liang of silver annually in minor revenues during the 16th century. Of this amount, 360,000–850,000 was generated by the Ministry of Revenue.
Government spending
During the early years of the Ming dynasty, the majority of the grain collected in taxes was used to feed soldiers. As time passed, the distribution of taxes shifted and by the 16th century, there was a significant change. In northern China, a large portion of the taxes were claimed by members of the imperial family, who had multiplied in number. This led to a situation where, in 1502, the tax revenues in the provinces of Shanxi and Henan were not enough to satisfy the claims of the descendants of the dynasty's founder. In the late 16th century, due to a lack of funds, many members of the imperial family went unpaid for decades, resulting in mass public protests. In the southern provinces, although there were not as many princes living there, the taxes collected—rarely collected in full (in the 16th century, collecting 80% of prescribed taxes was considered a notable success for a county magistrate)—were often not enough to equip local military units after the main taxes were paid to the capital. Additionally, emperors frequently granted tax exemptions in cases of natural disasters, the ascension of a new ruler, the birth of an heir, or the writing off of uncollectible debts.
As the decades and centuries passed, the size of the imperial household grew significantly. The initial few hundred eunuchs multiplied to ten to thirty thousand between the mid-15th and mid-16th centuries, and by the end of the dynasty, the number may have reached as high as seventy thousand. This growth in staff also led to an increase in expenses for the imperial palace, although efforts were made to reduce costs after a new emperor took the throne. Overall, the palace consumed approximately 20–25% of the tax revenue.
In times of financial strain, priority was given to the needs of higher offices and payments outside the county or prefecture, resulting in cuts to payments for local military garrisons and lower-ranking members of the imperial family. As a result, after the mid-15th century, less than 15% of the military units in the interior were actually functional, and even the Beijing Ministry of War acknowledged that 8 out of 10 soldiers had deserted long ago. On the northern border, the units maintained their combat capabilities and were reinforced when necessary, but in the southeast, the army had to be assembled from scratch.
Another problem was the low salaries of government officials. During the early years of the dynasty, these salaries were set at a significantly lower level compared to previous dynasties, amounting to only about one-fifth of what officials had received before. This meant that lower-ranking officials were earning the same income as a peasant, while high-ranking officials earned only ten times more. In the 14th and 15th centuries, when the government faced financial shortages, they resorted to paying officials in paper money at an unrealistic exchange rate, or even forcing them to accept non-monetary items such as paintings, calligraphy, and pepper instead of the necessary rice, cloth, cash, and precious metals. The real value of these salaries decreased to as low as one-fifth or even one-twentieth of the original amounts. Although salaries were eventually converted to silver in the 16th century, they still remained woefully inadequate—for example, a prefect received only 62.05 liang per year, while a county magistrate earned a mere 27.49 liang per year. In comparison, a day laborer earned 12 liang for the same period. As a result, very few officials were able to sustain themselves solely on their salaries.

In the 1590s, the price of grain for tax purposes was 1.25 liang per dan, and even higher on the market, reaching up to 5 liang per dan in the northern borderlands. This had a significant impact on small farmers, who were forced to become tenants and pay high rents in addition to taxes. In some cases, they were even required to give up two-thirds of their harvest as taxes. By the end of the 16th century, 90% of peasants in the lower Yangtze region had lost their land and become tenants.
At the same time, cities flourished as the influx of free labor stimulated the development of crafts, mining, and transportation, although not everyone who migrated to the cities was able to find work. The high number of unemployed and homeless individuals led to an increase in beggars, thieves, and bandits. The desperation of the poor also led to the selling of their children or themselves into service, essentially becoming slaves. In one county, it was reported that 20–30% of the population was living in these conditions. The scholar Gu Yanwu (1613–1682) later recalled that when someone was appointed to a government position, thousands of people would offer to serve them. In response, the court increased the number of eunuchs. During the crisis years, many unemployed young men even resorted to castrating themselves in hopes of finding employment at the imperial court. In 1620, there were reportedly 20,000 such applicants in Beijing alone.
As the focus shifted from land to trade and manufacturing, land prices fell and eventually collapsed by the end of the 16th century. While the merchant class grew stronger and the urban population, commercial agriculture, production of handicrafts and manufactured goods, and use of money all increased, the lower classes of the peasantry saw their situation worsen.
To address the persistent trade deficit with the Ming dynasty, silver from all over the world flowed into China. In the first decade of the 17th century, Japan alone contributed 33–48 tons per year, with even more coming from other parts of the world. China was the largest recipient of American silver through the Philippines, receiving 2–3 million pesos (57.5–86.25 tons) annually in the 17th century. Approximately 20% of American silver was sent directly to the Philippines and China, while the rest was routed through Europe and the markets of Central Asia. Ultimately, half of the American silver production ended up in China. In total, at least 250–265 tons of silver entered China each year in the first third of the 17th century, although the actual amount was likely much higher. Despite these international connections, China was negatively impacted by the European depression of the 1620s, which caused trade from the Philippines to decrease significantly (from 41 to 6 ships per year in Manila). It was not until the 1630s that trade resumed.
Final crisis (1620s–1640s)
The Ming economy experienced a decline in the 1620s, which was exacerbated by a financial crisis caused by a shortage of silver currency. This shortage was a result of the actions of English and Dutch pirates, who were supported by their governments in their efforts to weaken the economic power of their Catholic enemies. Additionally, Philip IV of Spain () restricted the export of silver from the Americas to China and attempted to monopolize trade by sending ships carrying Peruvian silver to Manila from Spanish ports. In 1639, the Japanese government also cut off trade with European states, further limiting the supply of silver to China. Although some silver continued to flow in from Japan, it was in limited quantities, while the loss of South American silver had a more significant impact. Some argue that the increase in the value of silver in the 17th century was due to a decrease in demand for goods, rather than a decrease in the amount of silver in circulation.

These events all occurred around the same time and had a combined effect on the value of silver, making it difficult for many Chinese provinces to pay their taxes and levies. As the value of silver increased, it became less desirable to use as currency, leading to a decrease in its circulation and an inflation of copper coins. By the 1630s, one thousand copper cash coins were equivalent to one liang of silver, but by 1640, it was only half a liang, and by early 1643, it was only one-third of a liang. This had a devastating impact on peasants, as taxes were still assessed in silver while local trade—selling surpluses and purchasing manufactured goods—was conducted using copper coins.

Beginning in the 1620s, famine became a regular occurrence in northern China due to dry, cold weather and the resulting shortening of the growing season. This cooling period is now known as the Little Ice Age. The famine, along with increasing taxes, desertion, a weakened poor relief system, floods, and the central government's failure to properly manage irrigation and flood control projects, led to high mortality rates, impoverishment, and brutality. The government, facing a loss of tax revenue, was unable to effectively address these issues.
In the 1620s, the conditions in the countryside were unbearable for the peasants, leading to continued rebellions. The northern region of China was particularly affected, as it was ravaged by a war between the government army and the rebels who had risen up in Li Zicheng's rebellion. As a result, in the 1630s, many poor and hungry individuals fled to the cities, where they were forced to resort to begging and stealing for survival. This mass migration left entire counties in the countryside deserted, and the wealthy gentry were shocked by the extent of the poor's resentment towards the rich. The situation was further exacerbated by a severe famine in Henan, which drove hundreds and thousands of angry peasants to join Li Zicheng, causing the collapse of the state administration. In 1629, the government made a 30% cut in postal spending, resulting in a significant decline in communication and making it uncertain for officials to expect their messages to reach the center. The situation was worsened by a famine in Jiangxi in 1637 and an epidemic that swept through northern China in 1641, reaching as far as Jiangnan. General Wu Sangui, who was in command of the Ming frontier army north of Beijing, felt compelled to submit to the Manchu-led Qing dynasty in order to defeat the rebels. With the support of landowners and gentry, the Qing army swiftly defeated the rebels and gained control of northern China. In the following years, they also conquered the southern regions of the country. The wars resulted in a significant loss of life, leaving only a third of the population in some areas of the devastated north, while southern cities were also greatly affected.
